questions.text: A patient is being treated with phenobarbitone. Which of the following is inhibited? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complex I → coenzyme Q


Phenobarbitone is known to affect the electron transport chain, specifically inhibiting the transfer of electrons from Complex I to coenzyme Q. Complex I, also known as NADH dehydrogenase and NADH CoQ oxidoreductase, takes hydrogen from NADH and transfers electrons to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone). This step is crucial in the electron transport chain as it initiates the flow of electrons, which is essential for ATP production. Phenobarbitone inhibits this specific step, disrupting the electron flow, which impairs cellular energy production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complex II → coenzyme Q: This step involves the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, a different pathway not directly affected by phenobarbitone.

 

Option C. Complex III → Cyt. C: This step transfers electrons from coenzyme Q to cytochrome C, an independent part of the electron transport chain not impacted by phenobarbitone.

 

Option D. Complex IV → oxygen: This final step involves the transfer of electrons to oxygen, forming water. Phenobarbitone does not inhibit this part of the chain.

 

Educational Objective:


Phenobarbitone specifically inhibits the electron transport between Complex I and coenzyme Q, disrupting ATP production.

questions.text: Fructosamine (which is used for assessing long term glycemic control in a person with hemolysis) is a glycated product of: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

Fructosamine is a compound formed when glucose binds to serum albumin, which is the most abundant protein in the blood. This glycated product provides an indicator of long-term glycemic control because it reflects the average blood glucose levels over the previous 2 to 3 weeks. Since it is primarily formed from the glycation of albumin, option d (Albumin) is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycosaminoglycan refers to a different type of compound, glycosaminoglycans, which are long, linear polysaccharides found in connective tissues.

 

Option B. Urea is a waste product removed by the kidneys and is not involved in fructosamine formation.

 

Option C. Fructose is a sugar but is not directly related to the formation of fructosamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose can be attached to proteins, albumin, and also to RBCs forming HbA1c. Fructosamine is term used for all the glycated proteins including glycated albumin.

 

 

 

In hemolysis patient, HbA1c analysis cannot be done because it will be falsely decreased due to damage to RBCs and loss of hemoglobin. So, fructosamine determination is used for these patients.

questions.text: A diabetic patient was advised exercise by the treating physician. The glucose transporter which is insulin sensitive is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glut 4

 

Glucose transporter 4 (Glut 4) is the insulin-sensitive glucose transporter found in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle. Insulin plays a key role in regulating glucose uptake in these tissues by promoting the translocation of Glut 4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane, thereby enhancing glucose entry into the cell. This insulin-mediated mechanism is crucial in maintaining blood glucose levels, especially during states of increased energy demand, such as exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glut 1: This glucose transporter is found in nearly all tissues, including the brain, and facilitates the basal uptake of glucose independently of insulin. It is not insulin-sensitive.

 

Option B. Glut 2: Glut 2 is mainly present in liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the renal tubules, where it helps regulate glucose levels.

 

Option C. Glut 3: This transporter is primarily located in neurons and the placenta, ensuring high-affinity glucose uptake in tissues with high glucose demand. It is not regulated by insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glut 4 is the only glucose transporter that is insulin-sensitive, primarily found in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle, where it facilitates glucose uptake in response to insulin.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of Hb

 

2,3-BPG binds to the globin part of hemoglobin. The binding of 2,3-BPG reduces the oxygen affinity of hemoglobin, promoting the release of oxygen in tissues where it is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This option is not accurate. 2,3-BPG does not directly bind to the heme group of hemoglobin. Instead, it interacts with the globin chains of hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Haem part of Myoglobin:

  • This option is not accurate. Myoglobin is a single-chain protein, and it does not contain heme groups like hemoglobin. Myoglobin directly binds oxygen to store it in muscle tissues, but it does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option D. Globin part of Myoglobin:

  • This option is not accurate. Myoglobin is a single-chain protein, and it does not contain globin chains like hemoglobin. Myoglobin directly binds oxygen in muscle tissues but does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3 BPG has negative charge whereas beta chain of hemoglobin has large positive charges due to amino acids His and Lys. Together they form the salt bridges (see fig) which promote formation of taut conformation and helps in deoxygenation.

questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies would you suspect in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3 deficiency

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia is suggestive of niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency. Vitamin B3 (also called niacin, nicotinic acid)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1/Thiamine deficiency: can manifest as wet beriberi (CVS features like heart failure and edema), dry beriberi (peripheral neuritis), or as Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis (in alcoholics). Dietary deficiency of thiamine inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6/Pyridoxine deficiency: causes Convulsions, hyperirritability, peripheral neuropathy (deficiency inducible by isoniazid and oral contraceptives), sideroblastic anemia (due to impaired hemoglobin synthesis and iron excess)

 

Option D. Vitamin B12/Cobalamin deficiency: causes Macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia, paraesthesia and subacute combined degeneration due to abnormal myelin. Associated with

↑ serum homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels, along with 2° folate deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Following image shows Casal’s Necklace & hyperpigmentation of sun-exposed limbs:

questions.text: Entry of glucose is insulin independent in all of them except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Adipose tissues

 

Glucose enters cells through GLUT (glucose transporter) proteins. Some are insulin-dependent, while others are not.

 

Adipose tissues:
•    Use GLUT4
•    Insulin-dependent
•    Insulin stimulates translocation of GLUT4 to membrane → increases glucose uptake

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. RBC (Red Blood Cells)
•    Use GLUT1
•    Insulin-independent

 

Option B. Pancreas (β-cells)
•    Use GLUT2
•    Insulin-independent
•    Glucose entry triggers insulin secretion

 

Option D. Brain
•    Uses GLUT1 (BBB) and GLUT3 (neurons)
•    Both are insulin-independent
•    Brain requires a constant glucose supply regardless of insulin


 

Educational Objective:

 

Major Glucose transporters and their function is summarized as:

questions.text:
Which of the following is true for hemolytic anemia ? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Indirect van den bergh test positive
  2. Direct van den bergh test positive
  3. Increased urine urobilonogen
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a and c


In hemolytic anemia, there is increased breakdown of red blood cells, which leads to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood. The indirect Vandenbergh test detects unconjugated bilirubin, which is increased in hemolytic anemia. Additionally, the increased breakdown of hemoglobin leads to greater production of urobilinogen, which is then excreted in urine in higher amounts. Therefore, both indirect Vandenbergh test positivity and increased urinary urobilinogen are characteristic findings in hemolytic anemia.



Direct Van den Bergh Test


Conjugated Bilirubin + Ehrlich’s Diazo Reagent → Reddish purple Azo compound(Gives colour immediately)

 

Indirect Van den Bergh Test (Doesn’t give colour immediately)
Unconjugated Bilirubin → Extraction with Alcohol → Gives colour (Water Insoluble)

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hemolytic anemia is characterized by a positive indirect Vandenbergh test (due to increased unconjugated bilirubin) and increased urine urobilinogen (due to increased hemoglobin breakdown).

questions.text: Patient with high triglycerides esterified with long chain fatty acid (LCFA) presents with fatigue and biopsy of muscle shows fat vacuoles. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine deficiency

 

Carnitine deficiency is a condition in which there is insufficient carnitine to transport long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation, which is the process that generates energy from fats. As a result, LCFAs cannot be oxidized and accumulate in tissues, leading to fatigue, muscle weakness, and the presence of fat vacuoles on muscle biopsy. The accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids is characteristic of carnitine deficiency because LCFAs bind to glycerol when they are not oxidized. This condition often presents with symptoms such as exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and, in severe cases, rhabdomyolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FA synthase defect: Fatty acid synthase (FAS) is an enzyme that helps in the synthesis of fatty acids in the body. A defect in FAS usually does not present with the clinical picture seen here since fatty acids can be provided through the diet. It is often benign and does not lead to the accumulation of fat vacuoles in muscles or the described clinical symptoms.

 

Option C. LPL defect: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is an enzyme that breaks down triglycerides in chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) into free fatty acids for tissue uptake. An LPL defect leads to type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by elevated triglycerides, pancreatitis, abdominal pain, and eruptive xanthomas, which do not match the clinical scenario described in the question.

 

Option D. LDL receptor defect: A defect in the LDL receptor results in type 2a hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by elevated LDL cholesterol levels, tendon xanthomas, and a higher risk of atherosclerosis. This condition does not involve the accumulation of fat vacuoles in muscle or present with fatigue related to long-chain fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carnitine is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation. Deficiency in carnitine leads to the accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids in muscle tissues, causing fatigue and exercise intolerance

choices.text: Carbon monoxide poisoning

questions.text: Identify the left curve, given the fact that the right curve is of adult hemoglobin.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

Explanation

 

  • The left curve is for myoglobin as it is a rectangular hyperbola curve which is characteristic of Michaelis Menton kinetics.
  • Fetal hemoglobin, CO poisoning and acidosis will shift the sigmoidal shape of hemoglobin saturation curve as shown in the image below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal hemoglobin: Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin, which shifts the curve to the left. However, the curve still maintains a sigmoidal shape.

 

Option C. Carbon monoxide poisoning: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin with a much higher affinity than oxygen, shifting the hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left and making it more difficult for oxygen to be released to tissues. This also retains the sigmoidal shape.

 

Option D. Acidosis: Acidosis generally causes a rightward shift of the hemoglobin oxygen dissociation curve, reducing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. This is the opposite of what is observed with myoglobin.

The left shift observed in the myoglobin curve reflects its high affinity for oxygen, distinguishing it from the sigmoidal curves seen in hemoglobin variations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myoglobin has a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve due to its single polypeptide chain and high oxygen affinity, contrasting with the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin due to its cooperative binding.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with complaints of poor feeding, vomiting, acidosis, and cataract. Urine Benedict’s test was positive, while urine glucose was negative. The enzyme defective in this case is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The symptoms described—poor feeding, vomiting, acidosis, cataract, and a positive Benedict’s test with negative urine glucose—are characteristic of classical galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This enzyme is crucial in the metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products. When this enzyme is deficient, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in tissues, leading to toxic effects including liver damage, cataract formation (oil drop cataract), and intellectual disability due to energy deficiency in the brain.

 

The positive Benedict’s test indicates the presence of a reducing sugar, which in this case is galactose, not glucose, explaining the negative glucose test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fructokinase: This enzyme is involved in fructose metabolism, specifically converting fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Its deficiency leads to essential fructosuria, a benign and asymptomatic condition that does not cause the symptoms observed in this case.

 

Option B. Sucrase: Sucrase breaks down sucrose into glucose and fructose. Sucrase deficiency primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming sucrose (common in sugarcane juice). It is unrelated to the clinical presentation described.

 

Option D. Lactase: Lactase is responsible for the digestion of lactose into glucose and galactose. Its deficiency causes lactose intolerance, characterized by diarrhea, gas, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy, but does not lead to acidosis or cataract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classical galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites, resulting in serious clinical symptoms including cataracts and liver damage.

choices.text: Beta oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Alpha oxidation of branched chain fatty acid
Omega oxidation of branched chain fatty acid

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid

 

Refsum's disease is a peroxisomal disorder caused by the impaired alpha-oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, which results in the buildup of phytanic acid in the body. This accumulation of phytanic acid is a characteristic feature of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in beta oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Beta oxidation is a different metabolic process.

 

Option C. Omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid: Refsum's disease is not caused by the defect in omega oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids. Omega oxidation is a different metabolic pathway.

 

Option D. Alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids: Refsum's disease primarily involves the defect in the alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids, not the alpha oxidation of dicarboxylic acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic of Peroxisomal pathways:

 

  • No ATP production in any of peroxisomal pathways
  • H2O2 is regularly formed which is neutralized by peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase.
  • Two pathways which occur in peroxisomes are:

1. α-Oxidation of branched chain fatty acids (BCFA)

2. Oxidation of Very Long Chain Fatty Acid (VLCFA)

 

Refsum's disease: Occur due to defect in α-oxidation of BCFA in peroxisomes due to defect in phytanic acid hydroxylase. So, Phytanic acid not oxidised.

  • Beta-oxidation occurs for saturated and even chain fatty acids like palmitic and stearic acid
  • In Omega-oxidation dicarboxylic acids are formed. In MCAD deficiency there is dicarboxylic acidosis and non-ketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MSH2

 

MSH2 stands for "MutS homolog 2." The gene is located on chromosome 2 and is not directly involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Instead, MSH2 is a key component of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) pathway. MMR is responsible for correcting errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches and small insertions or deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BRCA1: BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Option C. KU70: KU70, along with KU80, forms the Ku heterodimer (Ku70/Ku80), which is a crucial component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. NHEJ is a major mechanism for repairing double-strand DNA breaks, especially in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option D. ATM: The ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia mutated) gene codes for a protein kinase that plays a central role in the cellular response to double-strand DNA breaks. It activates a signaling cascade that leads to DNA repair and cell cycle control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: Detoxification of Xenobiotics for phase 1 reaction (Hydroxylation) require monooxygenase/cytochrome P-450 along with: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADPH

 

The detoxification of xenobiotics in phase 1 reactions, particularly hydroxylation reactions catalyzed by monooxygenases or cytochrome P-450 enzymes, requires reducing equivalents in the form of NADPH. NADPH serves as a cofactor that provides electrons for the enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NADH: NADH is not the primary cofactor used in phase 1 hydroxylation reactions.

 

Option C. FAD: FAD (Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide) is not typically involved in the hydroxylation reactions of xenobiotic detoxification in phase 1.

 

Option D. FADH2: Similar to FAD, FADH2 is not the primary cofactor required for the hydroxylation reactions involved in the detoxification of xenobiotics during phase 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this reaction, a xenobiotic undergoes hydroxylation with the help of oxygen and NADPH as a cofactor. The cytochrome P450 enzyme catalyzes this reaction, leading to the introduction of a hydroxyl group into the xenobiotic molecule, making it more water-soluble and facilitating subsequent conjugation reactions in phase 2 detoxification.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dihydrobiopterin reductase

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder where phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, cannot be properly metabolized due to enzyme deficiencies. In classical PKU, the deficiency is in phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, if phenylalanine hydroxylase levels are normal, as stated in the question, the problem lies elsewhere in the metabolic pathway. Dihydrobiopterin reductase is an enzyme that regenerates tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor necessary for phenylalanine hydroxylase function. If dihydrobiopterin reductase is deficient, tetrahydrobiopterin cannot be regenerated, leading to non-classical PKU despite normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tyrosine transaminase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of tyrosine, not in the initial conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine or the regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin, making it unrelated to PKU.

 

Option C. Dopa decarboxylase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of neurotransmitters like dopamine from DOPA, unrelated to phenylalanine metabolism or PKU.

 

Option D. Tyrosine hydroxylase: This enzyme converts tyrosine to DOPA and is involved in neurotransmitter synthesis, not in phenylalanine metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In non-classical phenylketonuria, the deficiency is in dihydrobiopterin reductase, not phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

 

Hybridoma technology → common methods used to produce monoclonal antibodies

 

In this process, antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are isolated from mice after immunizing the mice with specific antigen and are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to form hybrid cells, called hybridoma cell lines.

 

 

  • Even the most efficient fusion method will give only 1 to 2% of fused and viable hybridoma cells.
  • Hybridoma selection involve screening of the fused cells from the unfused cells. It is done using HAT media (a selection media).
  • HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine. The trick is that Aminopterin inhibits DHFR. So, it inhibits de-novo purine synthesis. Inhibition of DHFR also inhibits conversion of dUMP to dTMP.
  • Salvage pathway will occur, but only in B-cells, not myeloma cells. Myeloma cells are deficient in HGPRT .
  • Hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine allow cells with functional hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) genes to survive through salvage pathways.
  • Due to a limited life span, unfused B cells perish within a few days.
  • Unfused malignant neoplastic cells die as a result of the lack of HGPRT gene
  • Therefore, the remaining viable cells left in the media are the hybrid cells; these hybrid cells have the ability to grow and divide on HAT media because they have functional HGPRT gene from B lymphocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolytic pathway: This pathway is involved in the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate for energy production and is not specifically exploited in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis but is not the key pathway exploited in the hybridoma technique.

 

Option C. Kreb’s cycle: This cycle is part of cellular respiration and energy production but is not directly involved in the selection process of hybridoma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: A child was brought with pedal edema and cheilosis. Further investigations revealed cardiomegaly. What is the vitamin deficiency associated with this clinical presentation?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

The given clinical presentation with pedal edema and cardiomegaly is suggestive of wet beriberi, which is a consequence of thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, is a more likely candidate. Thiamine deficiency can manifest as cardiac beriberi, leading to an enlarged heart (cardiomegaly), which aligns with the clinical findings. Thiamine deficiency can also cause peripheral edema, such as pedal edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Riboflavin deficiency can lead to cheilosis, which is consistent with one of the symptoms observed. However, it is not typically associated with pedal edema or cardiomegaly.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency is not commonly associated with pedal edema, cheilosis, or cardiomegaly.

 

Option D. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes symptoms like dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It is not typically associated with cardiomegaly or pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 deficiency disorders

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother also complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. What enzyme is most likely deficient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycogen synthase

 

Glycogen synthase: This is the correct answer. Glycogen synthase is responsible for synthesizing glycogen from glucose. A deficiency in glycogen synthase would result in the inability to produce glycogen, which aligns with the liver examination findings of no glycogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle’s disease or glycogen storage disease type V) primarily affects skeletal muscle glycogen metabolism. Symptoms include muscle weakness, cramps, and exercise intolerance.

 

Option C. Debranching enzyme deficiency (Cori's disease or glycogen storage disease type III) presents with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and growth retardation. The liver would still contain glycogen, although with an abnormal structure.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke's disease or glycogen storage disease type I) is characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hepatomegaly, Renomegaly. In this case, glycogen is present in the liver but cannot be broken down efficiently into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen synthase is a key enzyme involved in glycogenesis, the process of synthesizing glycogen, which serves as a storage form of glucose in the liver and muscles. Glycogen synthase catalyzes the addition of glucose molecules to the growing glycogen chain by creating alpha-1,4-glycosidic linkages between glucose units. This enzyme is regulated by various factors, including insulin, which promotes glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase.

 

Mutations or dysregulation of glycogen synthase can lead to Glycogen Storage Disease 0 (GSD 0), a disorder resulting from mutations in the GYS2 gene encoding liver glycogen synthase. C/f include fasting hypoglycemia, hunger between meals, hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and other metabolic abnormalities due to impaired glycogen synthesis.

questions.text: Which micronutrient deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and white line of Frenkel on X-ray? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Vitamin C is crucial for the absorption of iron in the body as it converts ferric ion (Fe³⁺) to ferrous ion (Fe²⁺), the form in which iron is best absorbed in the intestine. A deficiency of vitamin C can impair iron absorption, leading to iron deficiency anemia. Additionally, vitamin C is essential for the post-translational modification of collagen, where proline is converted to hydroxyproline and lysine to hydroxylysine. This modification strengthens collagen fibers; without sufficient vitamin C, collagen becomes weak, leading to symptoms such as bleeding gums due to fragile blood vessels. The white line of Frenkel on X-ray is another characteristic sign of scurvy, a condition resulting from severe vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia (low neutrophil count), and hypopigmentation, but it does not cause bleeding gums or the specific X-ray findings mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron deficiency leads to anemia, but it does not cause bleeding gums or the white line of Frenkel on X-ray, which are specific to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option D. Zinc: Zinc deficiency is associated with delayed wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea, and immune dysfunction, but it does not cause the symptoms outlined in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C deficiency causes anemia, bleeding gums, and the white line of Frenkel on X-ray due to impaired iron absorption and defective collagen synthesis.

choices.text: Chloride secretion is decreased in sweat and increased in pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is decreased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid
Chloride secretion is increased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid

questions.text: True regarding CF (Cystic Fibrosis): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid:

 

Explanation:

 

In sweat glands, the defective CFTR leads to decreased chloride reabsorption, resulting in increased chloride secretion in sweat. Therefore, individuals with CF have elevated levels of chloride in their sweat, which is a diagnostic feature of the condition.

 

In the pancreas, the impaired CFTR function leads to decreased chloride secretion into pancreatic fluid. This results in the production of thick, sticky mucus in the pancreatic ducts, leading to pancreatic insufficiency. The pancreas is unable to release digestive enzymes properly into the small intestine, affecting the digestion of food.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene. CFTR is a chloride channel that regulates the movement of chloride ions across cell membranes. In individuals with cystic fibrosis, the function of CFTR is impaired.

choices.text: To break AT bonds high Tm is required
To break GC bonds low Tm is required
To break AT bonds low Tm is required
AT bonds and GC bonds need the same TM

questions.text: Which of the following is true? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To break AT bonds low Tm is required

 

To break AT bonds low Tm is required: This statement is correct. AT bonds are held together by two hydrogen bonds, which are relatively weak compared to GC bonds. Therefore, lower temperatures (low Tm) are required to break AT bonds, causing the DNA to denature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To break AT bonds high Tm is required: This statement is incorrect. The melting temperature (Tm) of DNA is the temperature at which the double-stranded DNA molecule begins to denature or separate into single strands. AT bonds (adenine-thymine) are held together by two hydrogen bonds, which are weaker than the three hydrogen bonds holding GC bonds (guanine-cytosine) together. Therefore, lower temperatures (relatively low Tm) are required to break AT bonds.

 

Option B. To break GC bonds low Tm is required: This statement is incorrect. GC bonds have a higher Tm compared to AT bonds because they are held together by three hydrogen bonds, making them more stable. So, higher temperatures (relatively high Tm) are required to break GC bonds.

 

Option D. AT bonds and GC bonds need the same Tm: This statement is incorrect. As explained above, AT bonds and GC bonds have different Tm values due to the difference in the number of hydrogen bonds holding them together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA, there are two hydrogen bonds between A and T and three hydrogen bonds between G and C. So, AT bonds will require a lower Tm (melting temperature) compared to GC bonds as less energy is required for breaking 2 bonds compared to three bonds.

questions.text: A skin rash gets exaggerated on sun exposure is repaired by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nucleotide excision repair

 

 

Exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays from the sun causes damage to DNA by inducing the formation of thymidine dimers, which are covalent linkages between adjacent thymine bases on a DNA strand. These dimers distort the DNA structure, interfering with replication and transcription.

 

Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is the primary mechanism used by cells to repair this type of damage. The NER pathway identifies the bulky lesions caused by thymidine dimers, excises the damaged section of DNA, and fills in the gap with the correct nucleotides using a DNA polymerase.

 

A defect in this repair mechanism can lead to xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition characterized by extreme sensitivity to UV light, leading to severe sunburns, rashes, and a high risk of skin cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair: This mechanism repairs small, non-bulky DNA lesions such as single-base alterations, including deamination and oxidative damage. It does not correct UV-induced thymidine dimers.

 

Option B. Double-stranded DNA break repair: This repair mechanism is involved in fixing double-strand breaks, which occur due to radiation, replication errors, or certain chemicals. It does not address thymidine dimers.

 

Option C. Mismatch repair: Mismatch repair corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as incorrect base pairing (e.g., A-C instead of A-T). It is not involved in repairing damage from UV light exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleotide excision repair is the primary DNA repair mechanism that corrects damage caused by UV light, such as thymidine dimers.

choices.text: Niemann pick disease
Fish eye disease

questions.text: Identify the given image: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gaucher’s disease

 

  • Gaucher's disease is an inherited genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of a fatty substance called glucocerebroside in various organs, particularly the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • Symptoms include bone pain, anemia, enlarged organs (hepatosplenomegaly), a swollen and painful belly, easy bruising, and fatigue.
  • Gaucher's disease is most common in Jewish people of Eastern and Central European descent (Ashkenazi).
  • It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase, which is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wolman's disease:

  • Wolman's disease is a rare autosomal recessive lipid storage disease.
  • It is caused by mutations in the LIPA gene, which encodes lysosomal acid lipase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down lipids.
  • Individuals with Wolman's disease have a deficiency of lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the accumulation of cholesterol and triglycerides in various organs, including the liver, spleen, and intestines.
  • Symptoms often appear in infancy and may include enlarged liver and spleen, abdominal distension, diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

 

Option C. Niemann-Pick disease:

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a rare inherited disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize fat (cholesterol and lipids) within cells.
  • There are several subtypes of Niemann-Pick disease, including types A, B, and C, each caused by different genetic mutations.
  • Symptoms can vary depending on the subtype but may include hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), neurological problems, and respiratory difficulties.
  • Type C Niemann-Pick disease, in particular, can lead to cognitive and motor impairment.

 

Option D. Fish eye disease:

  • Fish eye disease is a rare genetic disorder and is a variant of familial lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) deficiency.
  • It is characterized by a deficiency of the LCAT enzyme, which plays a role in cholesterol metabolism.
  • Fish eye disease leads to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and can cause eye problems, including corneal opacities and vision impairment.
  • Unlike the more severe form of LCAT deficiency, known as LCAT deficiency, Fish eye disease typically has milder symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows crumpled tissue paper appearance of macrophage cells (see images below) which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. This disease is a type of sphingolipidoses and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme β-glucosyl ceramidase.

questions.text: A farmer is on a maize-based diet and develops skin rashes on the face, neck, and hand. Which of the following should be given? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The farmer’s symptoms of skin rashes in sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, and hands are characteristic of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Maize-based diets are deficient in tryptophan, which is necessary for niacin synthesis in the body. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, with the dermatitis presenting as symmetrical, pigmented, and scaly skin rashes. Providing niacin supplementation is the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency causes beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not pellagra. The symptoms of thiamine deficiency are primarily neurological and cardiovascular, not dermatological.

 

Option C. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency leads to visual problems, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, and does not cause skin rashes typical of pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to anemia and neurological symptoms, including neuropathy and cognitive disturbances. It does not cause skin rashes or dermatitis associated with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin deficiency in individuals consuming a maize-based diet can lead to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Niacin supplementation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: The micronutrient deficient in a patient with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of skin and hair is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cu (Copper)

 

Copper deficiency can present with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of the skin and hair. Copper is a crucial cofactor for several enzymes, including tyrosinase, which is involved in the conversion of tyrosine to melanin, the pigment responsible for skin and hair color. When copper is deficient, melanin production decreases, leading to hypopigmentation. Additionally, copper plays a role in iron metabolism and immune function, which explains the anemia and neutropenia observed in copper deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zn (Zinc): Zinc deficiency is characterized by delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, hypogonadism, and diarrhea. While zinc is important for various enzymatic functions, it does not specifically cause hypopigmentation or the combination of anemia and neutropenia seen with copper deficiency.

 

Option B. Se (Selenium): Selenium deficiency is associated with Keshan disease, which primarily affects the heart and can lead to cardiomyopathy. Selenium plays a role in antioxidant protection but does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Fe (Iron): Iron deficiency primarily causes microcytic anemia, fatigue, and pallor. It does not lead to neutropenia or hypopigmentation of the skin and hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper deficiency is associated with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation due to its role in melanin synthesis and various other enzymatic processes.

questions.text: Which of the following are Methanol poisoning derivatives? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formic acid + Lactic acid

 

Methanol (CH3OH) is metabolized in the body by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase into formaldehyde (HCHO). This formaldehyde is further converted into formic acid (HCOOH), which is a primary toxic metabolite responsible for the harmful effects of methanol poisoning, including metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances, and organ damage.

 

Furthermore, formic acid inhibits the electron transport chain, particularly at complex IV (cytochrome C oxidase). This inhibition disrupts ATP production, leading to increased levels of NADH. Due to this blockage, pyruvate is converted to lactate, causing the accumulation of lactic acid, another metabolite associated with methanol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formic acid + Oxalic acid: Oxalic acid is not a metabolite of methanol poisoning but rather of ethylene glycol poisoning. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Option C. Glycolic acid and Oxalic acid: Both glycolic acid and oxalic acid are metabolites of ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. Hence, this choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Oxalic acid and Lactic acid: Oxalic acid is not a derivative of methanol poisoning; it is associated with ethylene glycol poisoning. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol poisoning primarily results in the formation of formic acid and lactic acid as toxic metabolites.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. Mark the correct biochemical changes which will be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urate and lactate levels

 

This patient with chronic alcoholism and gouty arthritis will most likely have elevated levels of lactate and urate.

 

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by alcohol dehydrogenase is accompanied by the reduction of NAD+ to NADH. This results in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio (Hence ruled out Option A).

 

 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions which require NAD+ are inhibited:

  1. Glycolysis
  2. Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favoured)
  3. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  4. Fatty acid oxidation

 

This decreased fatty acid oxidation leads to increased esterification and production of triacylglycerol, which causes fatty liver.

In addition to this, there is an increase in two reactions:

  • Pyruvate to lactate
  • Oxaloacetate to malate

 

Increased lactate leads to hyper-lactic-acidemia, which leads to increased renal reabsorption of urate and decreased excretion of uric acid. This results in aggravation of gout.

 

Alcoholics are deficient in thiamine which inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase and these all leads to lactic acidosis.

 

A decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis, leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio: This is incorrect as the NADH/NAD+ ratio is actually increased due to the metabolism of ethanol.

 

Option B: Increased urea and urate levels are not specifically associated with alcoholism and gouty arthritis. But urate levels may be increased due to gout, urea levels are not directly related to the condition.

 

Option D: Increased levels of alkaline phosphatase can be seen in alcohol-induced hepatitis due to intrahepatic cholestasis but is not directly related to gouty arthritis in a chronic alcoholic patient. Therefore, this option is less relevant compared to increased rate and lactate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains
Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation:

 

Option C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation: This is the correct explanation. 2,3 BPG binds to a specific site in hemoglobin's central cavity, which is surrounded by histidine and lysine residues. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, favoring the release of oxygen molecules from hemoglobin into the surrounding tissues. The formation of salt bridges as a result of this binding contributes to the release of oxygen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not directly affect ATP production or break links between globin chains.

 

Option B. It increases ATP production: This statement is not correct. 2,3 BPG is not involved in ATP production.

 

Option D. Inhibits Taut structure formation: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not inhibit the formation of the Taut structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production
  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) plays a crucial role in regulating oxygen delivery by binding to deoxyhemoglobin and stabilizing the T (taut) state, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thereby promoting oxygen unloading to tissues.

 

 

  • When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tangier’s disease

 

Tangier's disease is an inherited disorder characterized by significantly reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood. This condition can lead to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and organs. Individuals with Tangier's disease may have enlarged orange tonsils and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease as shown in the picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman's Disease: Wolman's disease is a severe form of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) deficiency, a rare genetic disorder. It is characterized by the complete absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the buildup of fats in various tissues and organs. Symptoms typically appear in infancy and may include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), diarrhea/steatorrhea (fatty stools), and vomiting. This condition can be life-threatening.

 

Option B. Gaucher's Disease: Gaucher's disease is another genetic disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It results in the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucocerebroside in various organs and tissues, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Common symptoms include an enlarged spleen and liver, anemia, low platelet counts, and bone abnormalities. There are different types of Gaucher's disease, and the severity can vary.

 

Option D. Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system. It is caused by the absence or deficiency of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A, which leads to the buildup of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nerve cells. Symptoms typically appear in early childhood and include developmental regression, loss of motor skills, and a cherry-red spot in the eye. Tay-Sachs disease is progressive and ultimately fatal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia

 

ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).

 

  • So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Enlarged lymph nodes
    • Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals. It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase

choices.text: Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes
Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts
Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys
Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys

questions.text: PTH increases Calcium in blood. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rapid release of calcium from bones and increased calcium reabsorption in kidneys:

 

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) primarily acts to increase the concentration of calcium in the blood. It achieves this through several mechanisms:

  1. Stimulation of osteoclasts to resorb bone, leading to the release of calcium from the bones.
  2. Increased absorption of calcium in the intestines.
  3. Stimulation of the kidneys to reabsorb more calcium, reducing its excretion in the urine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Rapid release of calcium by osteocytes: Osteocytes are embedded in the bone matrix and are not directly involved in the rapid release of calcium. Osteoclasts, on the other hand, are responsible for bone resorption.

 

Option B. Rapid release of calcium by osteoclasts: Osteoclasts are indeed involved in the rapid release of calcium from bones. However, the complete action of PTH includes not only osteoclast activity but also increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Option D. Increase calcium reabsorption in kidneys: While PTH does stimulate increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, the complete action also involves the rapid release of calcium from bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the role of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in regulating calcium levels in the blood and the mechanisms by which it accomplishes this task.

 

  • Role of PTH in Calcium Regulation: PTH is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands, which are small glands located in the neck. Its primary function is to regulate calcium homeostasis in the body, ensuring that blood calcium levels remain within a narrow and critical range.
  • Increase in Blood Calcium: PTH increases blood calcium levels by stimulating various physiological processes:
    • Stimulation of Osteoclasts: PTH activates osteoclasts, specialized bone cells responsible for breaking down bone tissue. This results in the release of calcium from the bones into the bloodstream.
    • Enhanced Calcium Reabsorption: PTH enhances the reabsorption of calcium by the kidneys. This means that less calcium is excreted in urine, conserving it for use in the body.
    • Activation of Vitamin D: PTH indirectly stimulates the production of active vitamin D (calcitriol) in the kidneys. Calcitriol helps increase calcium absorption from the digestive tract, further contributing to higher blood calcium levels.
  • Negative Feedback Loop: The regulation of PTH secretion is tightly controlled by a negative feedback loop. When blood calcium levels drop below the normal range, the parathyroid glands release PTH, which acts to raise calcium levels. Once calcium levels return to normal, PTH secretion decreases, preventing excess calcium in the blood.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false
Assertion is false but Reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion: PKU is characterized by mousy odour(INICET NOV 2022)

 

Reason: Tyrosine and norepinephrine are not found in PKU
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

 

In PKU there is musty odour due to the formation of phenylketones. So, assertion in itself is true but the reason given is not the correct explanation of assertion.

 

In PKU, as the phenylalanine to tyrosine conversion is inhibited, and tyrosine is also required for formation of NE, so both will not be formed. So, reason is a correct statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PKU is characterized by a mousy odor due to the accumulation of phenylketones, while the absence of tyrosine and norepinephrine is a result of the metabolic block but is not the cause of the odor.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B deficiency

 

Vitamin B deficiency: This is the correct answer. The symptoms given in question are suggestive of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is caused by a deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine). Chronic alcoholism can lead to thiamine deficiency, which results in neurological symptoms like those described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A deficiency: Vitamin A deficiency typically presents with different symptoms, such as night blindness and skin issues, and is not related to the neurological symptoms seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to various bone related problems like Rickets and Osteomalacia, but it is not associated with the specific symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements seen in this case.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily presents with symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, and bleeding gums. It is not related to the neurological symptoms described in the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke encephalopathy – An acute, reversible but life-threatening condition. Clinical Vignette include Confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Nystagmus, Ataxia.

questions.text: A mother brought her 14-year-old mentally retarded child with complaints of joint pain and an irresistible urge to bite his fingers and lips. On investigation, his serum uric acid level was found to be elevated. The child is likely suffering from which disorder? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lesch-Nyhan syndrome


Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme plays a critical role in the purine salvage pathway, where it helps recycle hypoxanthine and guanine back into nucleotides rather than allowing them to degrade into uric acid. In the absence of HGPRT, there is an excessive accumulation of uric acid, leading to symptoms such as joint pain, gout, and hyperuricemia. The classic symptoms of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome include severe neurological dysfunction, self-mutilating behaviors like biting fingers and lips, and elevated uric acid levels, which perfectly match the clinical scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Xanthine oxidase deficiency: Xanthine oxidase is an enzyme involved in purine metabolism, specifically converting xanthine into uric acid. A deficiency would lead to low uric acid levels, not elevated levels as seen in this patient. Symptoms of self-mutilation and neurological issues are not associated with xanthine oxidase deficiency.

 

Option B. Thymidylate synthetase deficiency: Thymidylate synthetase is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine metabolism, not purine metabolism, and it does not affect uric acid levels. Deficiency would result in impaired DNA synthesis but not the symptoms seen here, such as self-mutilation and elevated uric acid.

 

Option D.  CPSII defect: CPSII (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis. Its deficiency leads to disorders related to pyrimidine metabolism but does not cause hyperuricemia, joint pain, or self-mutilation as observed in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by severe neurological dysfunction, self-mutilating behavior, and elevated uric acid levels due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme HGPRT.

questions.text: A patient present with an X-ray showing cardiomegaly, along with symptoms of hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pompe's disease


Pompe's disease, also known as Type II glycogen storage disease, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (also known as alpha-glucosidase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen in the lysosomes. Without this enzyme, glycogen accumulates within the lysosomes, leading to lysosomal storage disease. The clinical features of Pompe's disease include cardiomegaly, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, macroglossia, and the characteristic "floppy baby" syndrome due to severe muscle weakness. The disease primarily affects the heart and skeletal muscles, often leading to heart failure as seen in the presented X-ray with cardiomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebstein anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect involving the tricuspid valve but does not present with hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, or the "floppy baby" syndrome seen in Pompe's disease. Ebstein anomaly primarily affects the heart, causing cyanosis and heart failure but lacks the systemic metabolic features of Pompe's.

 

Option C. Transposition of great arteries: This is another congenital heart defect characterized by the abnormal arrangement of the heart's major arteries. While it presents with severe cardiopulmonary symptoms such as cyanosis and heart failure, it does not cause hypotonia, macroglossia, or hepatomegaly, distinguishing it from Pompe's disease.

 

Option D.  Von Gierke's disease: Von Gierke's disease (Type I glycogen storage disease) affects liver metabolism, leading to severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, renomegaly, and metabolic derangements such as lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia. However, it does not involve cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, or "floppy baby" syndrome, making it an incorrect diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Pompe's disease is characterized by the combination of cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and macroglossia, often presenting as "floppy baby" syndrome due to lysosomal storage of glycogen.

questions.text: Match the following Amino acid products: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-1, C-2, D-4

 

  • Tyrosine (A) → Norepinephrine (3): Tyrosine is a precursor for catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. It's also used for melanin and thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Tryptophan (B) → melatonin (1): Tryptophan is metabolized to serotonin, which is then converted to melatonin. Tryptophan is also a precursor for niacin (vitamin B3).
  • Glycine (C) → Glutathione (2): Glycine is one of the three amino acids that make up glutathione (along with glutamate and cysteine). Glycine is also used in heme synthesis, creatine synthesis, and bile acid conjugation.
  • Histidine (D) → Histamine (4): Histidine undergoes decarboxylation (removal of the carboxyl group) to form histamine, which is an important inflammatory mediator and neurotransmitter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amino Acid Conversions

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Ca2+

 

  • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.

 

Option C. Glucose:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):

 

  • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers Pi, uses PLP (B6) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

choices.text: Hip Circumference
HDL
Glucose
Hypertension

questions.text: Which is not considered in the diagnosis of Metabolic syndrome: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip Circumference

 

Option A: Hip circumference is not typically considered as a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. The criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome usually include a combination of factors such as central obesity (usually measured by waist circumference), elevated blood pressure, elevated fasting glucose, high triglycerides, and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein): HDL cholesterol is considered in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome. Low levels of HDL are one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option C. Glucose: Elevated fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. Hypertension: High blood pressure is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome. Hypertension is considered a component of metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. The diagnosis of metabolic syndrome involves the assessment of specific criteria related to various health parameters. The objective is to identify individuals at higher risk for these conditions so that preventive measures can be taken.

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

 

Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are zymogens of serine proteases that contain glutamic acid residues. These residues undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation via gamma-glutamyl carboxylase to form gamma-carboxy glutamic acid residues. This enables them to bind calcium ions (Ca2+), which is necessary for their activation and subsequent blood clot formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factors II, VIII, IX, X: Factor VIII is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation but does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option C. Factors II, VII, IX, XI: Factor XI is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is activated by thrombin and does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option D. Factors II, VIII, X, XI: Neither Factor VIII nor Factor XI are zymogens that require gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. They do not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.

 

Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

questions.text: Decreased transferrin saturation is seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

  

Transferrin saturation is a measure of the percentage of transferrin (iron-transporting protein) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, there is a lack of sufficient iron to saturate transferrin, leading to a decreased transferrin saturation. This occurs because the body has insufficient iron for proper incorporation into hemoglobin and other iron-containing proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemochromatosis: In hemochromatosis, there is an excessive absorption and accumulation of iron in the body. This condition leads to increased transferrin saturation, as the body has an excess of iron.

 

Option C. Macrocytic anemia: Macrocytic anemia refers to anemia with larger-than-normal red blood cells. It is commonly associated with deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folic acid. Transferrin saturation is not typically a characteristic feature of macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Hemosiderosis: Hemosiderosis refers to the deposition of excess iron in tissues. Like hemochromatosis, it is associated with increased transferrin saturation due to iron overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of transferrin saturation and how it relates to various conditions related to iron metabolism. Decreased transferrin saturation is typically seen in conditions of iron deficiency, such as iron deficiency anemia, where there is insufficient iron to fully saturate transferrin.

choices.text: Increases insulin sensitivity and supports glucose metabolism
It is a histone deacetylase and it causes chromatin condensation
It increases the life span
It is stimulated by niacinamide

questions.text: True about sirtuins are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is stimulated by niacinamide

 

This statement is incorrect. Sirtuins require NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) as a substrate for their enzymatic activity. During the process, NAD+ is converted to nicotinamide (niacinamide). The presence of niacinamide actually inhibits the activity of sirtuins, not stimulates it (option D is false).

 

Other Options

 

Sirtuins (Silent Mating Type Information Regulation Proteins) are a family of proteins that play a role in cellular regulation and are involved in various biological processes, including aging, transcription, and stress resistance.

 

Option A. Increases insulin sensitivity and supports glucose metabolism: Sirtuins improve glucose metabolism by increasing insulin sensitivity, thus supporting the efficient utilization of glucose in the body (option A is true).

 

Option B. It is a histone deacetylase and it causes chromatin condensation: Sirtuins have histone deacetylase activity. This activity removes acetyl groups from histones, resulting in a positive charge on the histones. The positive charge leads to tight binding of histones to DNA due to charge-charge interactions, leading to chromatin condensation (option B is true).

 

Option C. It increases the life span: Sirtuins are associated with the delay of the aging process and have been shown to extend the lifespan in various organisms by participating in DNA base excision repair and other cellular processes (option C is true).

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Sirtuins are involved in improving insulin sensitivity, supporting glucose metabolism, causing chromatin condensation through histone deacetylation, and extending lifespan. However, they are not stimulated by niacinamide; instead, niacinamide inhibits their activity.

questions.text: In the shown image, which one of the following is a source of vitamin B1? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) is primarily found in whole grains, cereals, nuts, and legumes. The primary source of thiamine in grains is the aleurone layer, which is often removed during the polishing process of white rice. However, parboiling rice can help preserve this layer, retaining the vitamin B1 content. In the provided image, the food item labeled 'A' is rice, which is a source of vitamin B1, especially when not overly polished.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This option does not represent a significant source of vitamin B1. It appears to be a different food item that does not contain high levels of this vitamin.

 

Option C. The item labeled 'C' is not a grain or a food typically high in vitamin B1.

 

Option D. This option is also not a significant source of vitamin B1, as it does not represent a grain or similar food known for its thiamine content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 is primarily found in the aleurone layer of grains, which can be removed by polishing but is preserved in parboiled rice.

questions.text: A patient presents with xanthomas on the Achilles tendon. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. A hallmark of this condition is the presence of tendon xanthomas, which are cholesterol deposits typically found in tendons, most commonly in the Achilles tendon. This condition is caused by mutations affecting the LDL receptor or apolipoprotein B, which impair the clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The Achilles tendon xanthomas are a distinctive feature that helps differentiate familial hypercholesterolemia from other lipid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tangier's disease: Tangier's disease is characterized by very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and the presence of orange-colored tonsils due to the accumulation of cholesterol esters. It does not cause tendon xanthomas, especially on the Achilles tendon, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Familial hyperchylomicronemia: This condition involves elevated triglycerides due to the accumulation of chylomicrons, often leading to eruptive xanthomas rather than tendon xanthomas. It is primarily associated with defects in lipoprotein lipase or apolipoprotein C-II and is not associated with the specific finding of Achilles tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D. Familial Dysbetalipoproteinemia: This condition, associated with a defect in apolipoprotein E, leads to increased levels of both cholesterol and triglycerides, often resulting in palmar xanthomas or tuberous xanthomas, not the specific Achilles tendon xanthomas seen in familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is associated with high LDL cholesterol levels and the presence of tendon xanthomas, particularly on the Achilles tendon

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dL) and LDL 220 mg/dL were found to be raised. What is the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LDL receptors defect

 

The patient's symptoms of multiple tendon xanthomas, elevated serum cholesterol, and high LDL levels indicate Type II hyperlipoproteinemia, commonly known as familial hypercholesterolemia. This condition is primarily caused by a defect in LDL receptors, leading to impaired clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The resulting elevated LDL levels promote cholesterol deposition in tendons, forming xanthomas. Treatment typically focuses on reducing LDL cholesterol levels through diet, medication, or in severe cases, LDL apheresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: This defect leads to Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by high levels of chylomicrons and triglycerides, but not elevated LDL or cholesterol. Symptoms typically include pancreatitis and eruptive xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Apo E defect: Apo E defect leads to Type III hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as dysbetalipoproteinemia. This condition is associated with elevated remnants of chylomicrons and VLDL, resulting in palmar xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas, and does not specifically cause the high LDL levels seen in this patient.

 

Option D. LCAT deficiency: LCAT deficiency affects HDL cholesterol conversion to cholesterol esters and does not directly affect LDL levels. It is associated with conditions such as Norum disease or fish eye disease, presenting with corneal opacity and hemolytic anemia rather than tendon xanthomas or elevated LDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDL receptor defects cause familial hypercholesterolemia, characterized by elevated LDL, cholesterol levels, and tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: A healthcare professional nurse was ordered by a doctor to take patient’s blood sample for glucose estimation. She took this patient’s sample at 8 a.m. which of the following is used to inhibit glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium fluoride


When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.
 

Sodium fluoride is the most commonly used glycolysis inhibitor in blood collection tubes for glucose testing.
 

Mechanism: It inhibits the enzyme enolase in the glycolysis pathway, effectively halting glucose breakdown.
 

Often combined with potassium oxalate (an anticoagulant) in a gray-top tube for glucose measurement.

 

Other options:


Option A. Sodium citrate – Anticoagulant used mainly for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, aPTT). It works by binding calcium, not by inhibiting glycolysis.
 

Option B. Potassium oxalate – Anticoagulant that binds calcium, but does not stop glycolysis on its own. It’s used in combination with sodium fluoride in gray-top tubes.
 

Option D. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) – Anticoagulant used for hematology tests (CBC, ESR). It binds calcium but doesn’t prevent glycolysis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

 

When a blood sample is taken for glucose estimation, it’s important to prevent glycolysis (the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells and leukocytes after collection), because glycolysis would artificially lower the measured glucose level.

questions.text: All are used in recombinant DNA technology (genetic engineering) except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isomerases

 

Isomerases are not used in recombinant DNA technology. Isomerases are enzymes that catalyze structural rearrangements within a molecule, converting one isomer to another. They don't have applications in genetic engineering techniques where cutting, joining, or modifying DNA sequences is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatases: These are used in recombinant DNA technology. Alkaline phosphatase removes terminal phosphate groups from DNA, which is useful in preventing unwanted ligation reactions in DNA cloning.

 

Option B. CRISPR Cas9:
 

CRISPR/CAS 9 System:

  • Causes double strand break
  • CROSPR- Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats
  • Cas-9: CRISPR associated endonuclease
    • This endonuclease is guided by CRISPR for cutting site
  • It is an immune system in bacteria against bacteriophages
    • Memory of bacteriophage infection and immunity is transferred to future generation also. So protect may future generations from viruses

Uses

  • Can be adopted to be used in eukaryotes for purposes like
    • Gene deletion
    • Exogenous gene insertion
    • Multigene editing possible
    • Altering gene transcription and regulation 

 

Option D. Terminal transferase: This enzyme is used in recombinant DNA technology to add nucleotides to the 3' OH end of DNA, which is useful in various molecular biology applications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isomerases, which catalyze structural rearrangements within molecules, are not used in recombinant DNA technology or genetic engineering, while phosphatases, CRISPR Cas9, and terminal transferase are utilized in these techniques.

questions.text: A patient's relatives sent a message on social media to the consulting doctor, unaware about the other investigations. But he mentioned that urinary coproporphyrin is positive. What is the probable cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lead poisoning

 

Lead poisoning is known to interfere with the heme synthesis pathway by inhibiting key enzymes such as delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase, coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and ferrochelatase. The inhibition of coproporphyrinogen oxidase leads to an accumulation of coproporphyrin in the urine, which is a hallmark of lead poisoning. This accumulation makes urinary coproporphyrin a valuable diagnostic marker for lead toxicity, as indicated in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers. It primarily affects the respiratory system and does not cause an increase in urinary coproporphyrin levels.

 

Option C. Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, affecting lung tissue. It does not influence heme synthesis or cause elevated urinary coproporphyrin levels.

 

Option D. Mercury poisoning: Mercury poisoning affects the nervous and renal systems but does not specifically impact the enzymes involved in heme synthesis. It does not lead to increased levels of urinary coproporphyrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead poisoning inhibits enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, resulting in elevated urinary coproporphyrin levels, which is a key diagnostic indicator.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cytochrome C oxidase inhibitor? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nitric oxide


Nitric oxide is not an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV of electron transport chain). NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme NO synthase and causes vasodilation. It has a role in physiological processes like erection and is inhibited by smoking, which can lead to erectile dysfunction.

 

Inhibitors of ETC Complexes

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Carbon monoxide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Carbon monoxide is part of the mnemonic "i'd" which includes carbon monoxide, cyanide, hydrogen sulfide, and sodium azide as inhibitors of complex IV.

 

Option C. Hydrogen sulfide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Hydrogen sulfide is listed among the substances that inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
