Option D. Cyanide: This is an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV). Cyanide is included in the list of substances that inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:


Nitric oxide (NO) is not an inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase (complex IV), while carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulfide, and cyanide are inhibitors of this complex IV  in the electron transport chain.

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms of dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The patient's symptoms—dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline (dementia)—represent the classic triad of pellagra, which is associated with niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is commonly summarized as the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. In severe untreated cases, it can lead to a fourth "D," which is death. Niacin deficiency can occur due to poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or conditions that affect tryptophan metabolism, such as Hartnup disease and carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to beriberi, which manifests as dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy) or wet beriberi (cardiac failure). It can also cause Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff's psychosis, particularly in alcoholics, but it does not cause dermatitis or diarrhea.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, depression, and seizures. It does not typically cause the 3D symptoms seen in pellagra unless it indirectly leads to niacin deficiency by impairing tryptophan metabolism.

 

Option D. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency primarily affects vision, immune function, and skin health, causing conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia, but it does not cause diarrhea or cognitive decline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is primarily caused by niacin deficiency.

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV

 

The questions is related to genetic material of different organisms or viruses and their base pairing rules. In DNA, adenine (A) always pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) always pairs with guanine (G). However, in RNA, which is the genetic material of some viruses like HIV, thymine is replaced by uracil (U) in base pairing. So, in RNA, adenine pairs with uracil.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli (Escherichia coli): E. coli is a bacterium, and its genetic material is DNA. In DNA, adenine pairs with thymine, so the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option B. Mitochondrial DNA of humans: Mitochondrial DNA is also composed of DNA, and in DNA, adenine pairs with thymine. Therefore, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have dsDNA as their genetic material, so adenine pairs with thymine in their DNA. Thus, the number of adenine is equal to the number of thymine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus with RNA as its genetic material. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil. So, the number of adenine will not be equal to that of thymine.

choices.text: Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased
Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased
Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with diabetes has high increased LDL and VLDL because of (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hormone sensitive lipase increased & lipoprotein lipase decreased


In diabetes, there is either a deficiency of insulin or insulin resistance. Insulin normally inhibits hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). When insulin is deficient or not working properly, HSL activity increases while LPL activity decreases. HSL breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue, releasing fatty acids into circulation. Increased HSL activity leads to more triglycerides being broken down. Meanwhile, decreased LPL activity reduces the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins from the bloodstream. This combined effect results in elevated levels of VLDL and subsequently LDL in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hormone sensitive lipase and lipoprotein lipase both increased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, these two enzymes are regulated in opposite directions. While HSL is increased, LPL is decreased due to the lack of insulin's regulatory effect.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein lipase increased & hormone sensitive lipase decreased: This is the opposite of what occurs in diabetes. This pattern would be seen in a fed state with normal insulin action, not in diabetes.

 

Option D. Lipoprotein lipase and hormone sensitive lipase both decreased: This is incorrect because in diabetes, HSL is increased, not decreased. While LPL is indeed decreased in diabetes, both enzymes are not decreased.

 

Educational Objective: 


Diabetes, hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) activity is increased while lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity is decreased due to insulin deficiency or resistance, leading to elevated levels of VLDL and LDL.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD as he is always fatigued and has muscle cramps after exercise and the blood sample collected soon after exercise showed low glucose and lactate level. He became normal after resting for a while. Which of the following diseases is he most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McArdle disease

 

McArdle disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type V): This condition is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme myophosphorylase, which is essential for breaking down glycogen into glucose for energy during exercise. In McArdle disease, individuals experience muscle cramps, fatigue, and myoglobinuria (the presence of myoglobin in the urine) after exercise due to the inability to access stored glycogen for energy. Low glucose levels and lactate buildup can occur during exercise in individuals with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hers disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI): Hers disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme liver glycogen phosphorylase. It primarily affects the liver and leads to difficulties in releasing glucose from glycogen stores in the liver. This condition typically does not manifest with muscle symptoms like cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Option C. Cori's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III): Cori's disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme debranching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and muscles and can lead to muscle weakness, liver enlargement, and hypoglycemia. However, it does not typically present with the specific exercise-induced symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Andersen disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV): Andersen disease is a rare condition caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glycogen branching enzyme. It primarily affects the liver and can result in liver fibrosis. It does not typically cause muscle cramps or exercise-induced symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The treatment given to the patient presenting with a history of binge alcohol intake and symptoms of convulsions, altered sensorium, and plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiamine followed by dextrose


In patients with a history of chronic alcohol intake, thiamine deficiency is a common complication. Alcohol interferes with thiamine absorption and utilization, leading to deficiencies that can impact various metabolic processes, including carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine is a crucial cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA during glucose metabolism. Administering glucose without prior thiamine can precipitate acute thiamine deficiency symptoms, worsening the patient’s condition and potentially leading to Wernicke’s encephalopathy, a severe neurological disorder.

 

Therefore, in cases where hypoglycemia is present (as indicated by a plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL), the correct management is to first administer thiamine to replenish depleted stores and then follow with dextrose to correct the hypoglycemia safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25% dextrose: While dextrose is necessary to treat hypoglycemia, administering it before thiamine in a thiamine-deficient patient can worsen the deficiency, leading to serious neurological complications.

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This is used in the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not relevant in alcohol-induced hypoglycemia or thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine: While thiamine is part of the treatment, it alone does not correct hypoglycemia. Both thiamine and dextrose are necessary, in the correct order.

 

Educational Objective:


In alcohol-related hypoglycemia, always administer thiamine before dextrose to prevent the exacerbation of thiamine deficiency and associated complications.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused by the defect of which of the following organelles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes

 

Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisome biogenesis disorder caused by defects in peroxisomes. Peroxisomes are essential organelles involved in various metabolic processes, and their dysfunction leads to Zellweger syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in mitochondria. Mitochondria are responsible for energy production in cells, and defects in mitochondria lead to different diseases, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lysosomes: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in lysosomes. Lysosomes are responsible for breaking down cellular waste and are associated with lysosomal storage disorders, which are different from peroxisomal disorders like Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Nucleus: Zellweger syndrome is not primarily caused by a defect in the nucleus. It is a peroxisomal disorder, and the genetic mutations associated with Zellweger syndrome typically affect genes related to peroxisome biogenesis, not nuclear genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Zellweger syndrome, there are empty peroxisomes in all body cells causing defect in alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA. So, both phytanic acid and VLCFA accumulate. It is the most severe Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorder (PBD).

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is related to which of the following alcohols?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methyl alcohol

 

Option A. Methyl alcohol (Correct Answer): Hooch tragedies are typically associated with the consumption of illicit liquor that contains methanol. Methanol is toxic to the human body and can lead to serious health issues, including organ damage and even death, when consumed in significant amounts.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ethyl alcohol: Ethyl alcohol, also known as ethanol, is the type of alcohol commonly found in alcoholic beverages that are legally produced and regulated. It is not typically associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethylene glycol: Ethylene glycol is not related to hooch tragedies. It is a chemical compound used in products such as antifreeze and is highly toxic when ingested.

 

Option D. Hypoglycin: Hypoglycin is a naturally occurring toxin found in certain plants, such as the ackee fruit, and is not directly related to hooch tragedies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Country liquor can be categorised as spurious liquor or hooch when the amount of methane added could turn fatal. There are number of death cases reported every year due to consumption of such alcohol.

 

The metabolism of methyl alcohol is shown in figure below:

 

 

The formaldehyde and formic acid formed as products during the metabolism can cause severe metabolic acidosis, blindness and neurologic damage.

 

The treatment involves administration of ethanol or Fomepizole which act as competitive inhibitors of enzyme ADH and prevent the formation of these two products.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition exhibited by A. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Competitive inhibition

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the active site of the enzyme. In the given graph, the presence of inhibitor A results in an increase in Km (Michaelis constant), indicating decreased enzyme affinity for the substrate due to competition. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged, which is characteristic of competitive inhibition. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows that the lines intersect on the y-axis, confirming that Vmax is unaffected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive inhibition: This type of inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a decrease in both Km and Vmax. The lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot are parallel, unlike the competitive inhibition plot seen here.

 

Option C. Mixed inhibition: In mixed inhibition, the inhibitor can bind to both the enzyme alone and the enzyme-substrate complex. This results in changes to both Km and Vmax, depending on the binding affinity. The graph shows altered Vmax with an intersection that is not on the y-axis, differing from competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. Non-competitive inhibition: Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds to a site other than the active site, affecting the enzyme regardless of substrate binding. This results in decreased Vmax without altering Km, seen as lines intersecting on the x-axis in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, unlike the competitive inhibition pattern here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition is identified by an increased Km and unchanged Vmax, with intersecting lines on the y-axis of the Lineweaver-Burk plot

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in an unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADH dehydrogenase

 

Rotenone is a potent inhibitor of Complex I in the electron transport chain, which is also known as NADH dehydrogenase or NADH oxidoreductase. Complex I is responsible for transferring electrons from NADH to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone), a crucial step in cellular respiration and ATP production. By inhibiting Complex, I, rotenone disrupts the electron transport chain, leading to a significant reduction in ATP synthesis. This inhibition can result in decreased cellular energy and potential cellular damage, which explains the unconscious state observed in the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of Complex II in the electron transport chain, which is not affected by rotenone. Complex II facilitates the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, bypassing Complex I, which is why rotenone does not inhibit this step.

 

Option C. Cytochrome C: Cytochrome C is a small heme protein that plays a role in electron transfer between Complex III and Complex IV of the electron transport chain. Rotenone does not affect Cytochrome C, as it acts upstream at Complex I.

 

Option D. Cytochrome oxidase: Also known as Complex IV, this enzyme is responsible for transferring electrons from Cytochrome C to oxygen, the final electron acceptor. Inhibitors of Complex IV include cyanide and carbon monoxide, not rotenone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotenone specifically inhibits Complex I also known as NADH CoQ oxidoreductase (NADH dehydrogenase) in the electron transport chain, blocking electron flow and ATP production.

questions.text: The active site of enzyme is complimentary to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substrate

 

The active site of an enzyme is complementary to the substrate. The active site is a specific region of the enzyme where the substrate binds, forming an enzyme-substrate complex. This binding is highly specific and is often likened to a lock-and-key or induced-fit model. It provides a specific environment that facilitates the conversion of substrate into product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition state: The transition state refers to the intermediate state of a substrate as it undergoes a reaction and transforms into a product. While enzymes stabilize the transition state during catalysis, the active site itself is typically complementary to the substrate, not the transition state.

 

Option B. Allosteric activator: Allosteric activators bind to allosteric sites on enzymes, which are distinct from the active site. Allosteric regulation involves a change in the enzyme's conformation, affecting its activity.

 

Option D. Product: The active site is not complementary to the product. Once the reaction occurs, the product is released from the active site, allowing the enzyme to participate in another catalytic cycle with a new substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of the active site of an enzyme and its relationship to substrates. The active site of an enzyme is complimentary to the substrate, allowing specific interactions that enable the enzyme to catalyze a particular chemical reaction. It stabilizes the transition state of the reaction, facilitating the conversion of substrates into products.

choices.text: Uncoupling of electron transport from ATP synthesis
Water retention in inner mitochondrial space

questions.text: Increased H+ ions in the intermembrane space of mitochondria are due to? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of ATP synthase

 

Explanation:

 

In mitochondria, the electron transport chain (ETC) pumps H⁺ ions (protons) from the mitochondrial matrix into the intermembrane space, creating a proton gradient (proton motive force). ATP synthase (Complex V) then uses this gradient to drive ATP production by allowing H⁺ to flow back into the matrix.

 

What happens when ATP synthase is inhibited?

 

  • Protons continue to be pumped into the intermembrane space by ETC.
  • ATP synthesis stops because protons can't flow back through ATP synthase.
  • This leads to a buildup of H⁺ ions in the intermembrane space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uncoupling of electron transport from ATP synthesis

 

  • Uncouplers (like thermogenin or DNP) allow H⁺ to flow back into the matrix without making ATP.
  • This decreases H⁺ concentration in the intermembrane space — not increase it.

 

Option B. Increased ATP production

 

  • Increased ATP production means more protons are used up (flowing back into the matrix), thus reducing their concentration in the intermembrane space.

 

Option D. Water retention in inner mitochondrial space

 

  • This is unrelated to proton concentration or the function of the ETC.

 

Educational objective:

 

ATP is synthesized in mitochondria by a process called oxidative phosphorylation. The oxidation of substrates like carbohydrates, amino acids, or fats produces reducing equivalents (NADH, FADH2). These equivalents enter the electron transport chain and transfer a proton (H+) to the inter-membrane space. The inner mitochondrial membrane is not permeable to protons leading to the accumulation of H+ in the intermembrane space. The flow of these protons through the Fo releases the energy that phosphorylates ADP to form ATP.

 

Drugs that inhibit oxidative phosphorylation like oligomycin inhibit the flow of protons through Fo causing an increase in H+ ions in the intermembrane space.

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which of the following deletion? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylalanine at 508

 

  • Correct. Cystic fibrosis is primarily caused by the deletion of Phenylalanine at position 508 in the CFTR gene. This mutation leads to a malfunctioning CFTR protein, which results in the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tyrosine at position 508. The critical deletion is of Phenylalanine at this position.

 

Option C. Tryptophan at 508: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Tryptophan at position 508. The deletion of Phenylalanine at this position is the key mutation associated with cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Lysine at 805: Cystic fibrosis is not caused by the deletion of Lysine at position 805. The F508del mutation is the most common and well-known mutation in cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystic fibrosis is due to mutation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein by deletion of one codon which give rise to phenylalanine at position 508 of this protein. Mnemonic: F-fibrosis, F- Phenylalaine

 

This protein helps in movement of H2O and chloride ion in and out of cell and helps in the formation of mucus secretion and saliva.

 

In normal conditions, the channel allows the formation of thin layer of mucus. But in cystic fibrosis, a thick layer of mucus is formed (see fig) causing airway obstruction leading to infection and ultimately scarring of lung tissue.

questions.text: Which vitamin can be deficient in a patient who has undergone gastrectomy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency commonly occurs in patients who have undergone a gastrectomy because the parietal cells of the stomach, which produce intrinsic factor, are removed or significantly reduced. Intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. Without intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot form the necessary complex to be absorbed, leading to deficiency. Conditions such as atrophic gastritis, pernicious anemia, and autoimmune diseases that affect intrinsic factor can also result in similar deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is usually associated with malabsorption syndromes affecting fat absorption, not specifically with gastrectomy.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C absorption occurs primarily in the small intestine and is not directly affected by the absence of the stomach.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D absorption occurs in the small intestine and depends on fat absorption, which is generally not impacted by gastrectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency due to the loss of intrinsic factor produced by the stomach's parietal cells, which is essential for B12 absorption in the ileum.

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combination of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine – Transketolase

 

This is the correct combination. Consuming polished rice can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Transketolase is an enzyme involved in thiamine-dependent reactions, and its activity can be affected by thiamine deficiency, leading to various health issues, including beriberi, which is associated with thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin - Glutathione Reductase: This combination is not relevant to the consumption of polished rice. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and glutathione reductase is not directly related to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine - Transaminase: While thiamine deficiency can affect various enzymes, transaminase is not specifically associated with thiamine deficiency related to polished rice consumption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin - Transketolase: This combination is not relevant to polished rice consumption. Riboflavin deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and transketolase is not directly related to riboflavin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The consumption of polished rice leads to thiamine deficiency which leads to defective transketolase activity.

 

Polished rice undergoes milling, which removes the outer bran layer rich in B vitamins and other nutrients

questions.text: Methotrexate reduces the synthesis of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TMP

 

Methotrexate inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase, which is crucial for the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from dihydrofolate. Tetrahydrofolate is required for the synthesis of thymidylate (TMP), as it acts as a one-carbon donor in the conversion of deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP) by thymidylate synthase. By inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, methotrexate indirectly reduces the availability of tetrahydrofolate, thereby decreasing the synthesis of TMP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GMP: Guanosine monophosphate (GMP) synthesis is not directly affected by methotrexate. GMP is a purine nucleotide, and its synthesis primarily involves different enzymes that are not dependent on thymidylate synthase or dihydrofolate reductase.

 

Option C. CMP: Cytidine monophosphate (CMP) synthesis involves pathways that are independent of tetrahydrofolate and thymidylate synthase, so methotrexate does not significantly impact its production.

 

Option D. AMP: Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) is another purine nucleotide whose synthesis does not involve dihydrofolate reductase or thymidylate synthase, so methotrexate does not directly affect its synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to reduced synthesis of TMP by limiting tetrahydrofolate availability.

questions.text: A Patient had dietary Cu deficiency, which is required by lysyl oxidase to cross link the collagen, what is the diagnosis of the patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Menkes Disease


Menkes disease is caused by copper deficiency. Copper is required as a cofactor for lysyl oxidase, an enzyme necessary for collagen cross-linking. In Menkes disease, there is a defect in the ATP7A protein which is responsible for copper absorption. This leads to copper deficiency despite adequate dietary intake. In Menkes disease, copper deficiency is seen and lysyl oxidase is affected which results in defective and weak collagen synthesis leading to brittle hair.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Scoliosis: This is an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine, not directly related to copper deficiency or lysyl oxidase function. Scoliosis can have various causes including congenital, neuromuscular, or idiopathic factors.

 

Option C. Ehlers Danlos syndrome: This is a group of connective tissue disorders caused by defects in collagen synthesis or structure. In Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, the defect is in lysyl hydroxylase, particularly in the kyphoscoliotic type, not in lysyl oxidase.

 

Option D. Scurvy: This is caused by vitamin C deficiency, not copper deficiency. Vitamin C is required for collagen maturation through hydroxylation of proline and lysine, but this is a different process from the cross-linking function performed by lysyl oxidase that requires copper.

 

Educational Objective: 


Menkes disease is caused by copper deficiency which affects lysyl oxidase activity, an enzyme required for collagen cross-linking, resulting in weak collagen formation and characteristic symptoms including brittle hair.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)  Non competitive

 

Explanation :

 

The graph illustrates enzyme kinetics in the presence of an inhibitor, showing that the Km (Michaelis constant) remains the same, whereas the Vmax (maximum velocity) decreases. This pattern is characteristic of non-competitive inhibition. In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site, which alters the enzyme's function but does not affect the substrate's binding affinity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding at the active site. This increases Km but does not change Vmax.

 

Option B. Uncompetitive: In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax.

 

Option D. Suicidal: Suicidal inhibition involves the inhibitor binding irreversibly to the enzyme, effectively inactivating it. This type of inhibition is not typically represented by simple kinetic plots.

 

Educational Objective

 

Summary of effect of different Inhibitors

questions.text: A patient presented with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor aspect of the forearm. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as follicular hyperkeratosis, is a skin condition commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by the presence of keratotic papules, especially on extensor surfaces such as the forearms, thighs, and buttocks. The deficiency leads to abnormal keratinization of hair follicles, resulting in rough, bumpy skin, primarily affecting areas that are prone to friction or pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Darier’s disease: Darier’s disease is a genetic disorder characterized by wart-like blemishes on the body, particularly in seborrheic areas such as the scalp, forehead, chest, and back. It involves keratinization defects and does not specifically present with follicular hyperkeratosis on the extensor forearms.

 

Option C. Eruptive xanthoma: Eruptive xanthomas are yellowish papules associated with hyperlipidemia and usually occur on the buttocks, elbows, and knees. They are due to lipid deposits in the skin and do not involve follicular hyperkeratosis or specifically present on the extensor surfaces of the forearms.

 

Option D. Folliculitis: Folliculitis is an infection of the hair follicles, often presenting with small, red or pus-filled bumps. It is generally caused by bacterial infection and does not present as hyperkeratosis related to nutritional deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is linked to vitamin A deficiency and presents as follicular hyperkeratosis, particularly on extensor surfaces like the forearm.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with colicky pain. Following type of crystals were found on urine examination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystinuria

 

The urine examination shows hexagonal crystals, which are characteristic of cystine crystals. These crystals are pathognomonic of cystinuria, a genetic disorder that affects the renal reabsorption of dibasic amino acids, including cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. Cystinuria leads to the formation of cystine stones in the kidneys, bladder, and ureters, often presenting with colicky pain due to stone obstruction.

 

Cystine crystals appear as flat, hexagonal plates, which is a distinctive feature that helps differentiate them from other types of crystals seen in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ADPKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease): This condition involves the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney enlargement and dysfunction. It does not typically present with hexagonal crystals in the urine; the crystals seen are more commonly calcium oxalate.

 

Option B. Calcium oxalate stones: These stones are among the most common kidney stones and appear as envelope or dumbbell-shaped crystals, not hexagonal. They are usually related to hyperoxaluria and not cystinuria.

 

Option D. Glomerulonephritis: This condition involves inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys, leading to symptoms like hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension. It does not present with specific crystals like the hexagonal cystine crystals seen in cystinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hexagonal cystine crystals in urine are characteristic of cystinuria, a genetic disorder affecting the renal absorption of certain amino acids, leading to recurrent cystine stone formation.

questions.text: Selenocysteine is present in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione peroxidase

 

Option B. Glutathione peroxidase: Glutathione peroxidase is an enzyme that contains selenocysteine in its active site. It plays a vital role in protecting cells from oxidative damage by catalyzing the reduction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides using glutathione as a cofactor.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: Glutathione reductase is an enzyme involved in the reduction of oxidized glutathione (GSSG) back to its reduced form (GSH). It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option C. Thioredoxin peroxidase: Thioredoxin peroxidase (also known as peroxiredoxins) is a group of thiol-containing proteins involved in breaking down hydrogen peroxide during oxidative stress. It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option D. Thioredoxin oxidase: Thioredoxin oxidase is not a known enzyme. There is an enzyme called thioredoxin reductase, which is involved in maintaining the redox state of thioredoxin, but it does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are:
  1. Glutathione Peroxidase
  2. Thioredoxin Reductase
  3. Iodothyronine deiodinase
  • Codon for selenocysteine: UGA
  • This AA is formed by co–translational (during translation) modification (not by post-translational modification).

choices.text: Work only when in close conjugation with promoter region
Work only when in upstream of promoter region
They are very specific to the gene
Recruit chromatin and modify regulatory mechanisms

questions.text: True statement about the action of enhancers of gene expression?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recruit chromatin and modify regulatory mechanisms

 

  • This statement is correct. The primary function of enhancers is to recruit transcription factors and other regulatory proteins, which in turn modify chromatin structure and regulatory mechanisms. Enhancers play a crucial role in creating an open chromatin environment, making the promoter region accessible to transcription machinery, and enhancing gene expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Work only when in close conjugation with the promoter region: This statement is not entirely accurate. Enhancers do not have to be in close proximity to the promoter region to function. Enhancers can be located at varying distances from the promoter, even thousands of base pairs away. They exert their regulatory influence through long-range DNA looping interactions, so physical closeness is not a strict requirement.

 

Option B. Work only when in upstream of the promoter region: This statement is also incorrect. Enhancers can be located both upstream and downstream of the promoter region. They can even be within introns or elsewhere in the gene or intergenic regions. The position relative to the promoter varies and does not determine their functionality.

 

Option C. They are very specific to the gene: Enhancers are not always gene-specific. Some enhancers can influence multiple genes, especially in gene clusters. Their specificity is often determined by the combination of transcription factors they bind to and chromatin structure. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enhancers: Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences that play a crucial role in controlling gene expression. They can be located at varying distances from the gene they regulate and can function independently of their orientation or location (upstream, downstream, or within an intron). Enhancers work by recruiting transcription factors and other regulatory proteins. These proteins, in turn, facilitate the binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter region, ultimately leading to the initiation of transcription.  Enhancers can also recruit chromatin-modifying enzymes, leading to changes in chromatin structure and accessibility. This chromatin modification is a key mechanism in the regulation of gene expression.

 

Characteristics of Enhancers:

 

  1. Distance: Enhancers can act over long distances. They are not necessarily proximal to the promoter; they can be located upstream, downstream, or within an intron of the gene.
  2. Orientation: Enhancers can function in either orientation relative to the gene.
  3. Specificity: Enhancers are not always specific to a single gene; they can regulate the expression of multiple genes, and one gene can be regulated by multiple enhancers.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

D. Mitochondrial - 1. LHON (Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy):

LHON is caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA affecting the optic nerve and leading to vision loss.

 

A. AD (Autosomal Dominant) - 2. Myotonic Dystrophy:

Myotonic Dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by muscle wasting and myotonia, caused by an expanded repeat sequence in the DMPK gene.

 

B. AR (Autosomal recessive) 3. Cystic Fibrosis:

Cystic Fibrosis is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.

 

C. XR (X-Linked Recessive) 4. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy:

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the DMD gene, leading to progressive muscle degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different genetic disorders are inherited through various modes of inheritance: autosomal dominant (e.g., Myotonic Dystrophy), autosomal recessive (e.g., Cystic Fibrosis), X-linked recessive (e.g., Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy), and mitochondrial (e.g., LHON).

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscle and adipose tissues

 

Explanation:

 

GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. GLUT-2 allows the liver to take up glucose and store it as glycogen or use it for energy production, independent of insulin.

 

Option B. Pancreas: The pancreas also uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. In the pancreas, GLUT-2 plays a role in sensing blood glucose levels and regulating insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Placenta: The placenta uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. These transporters facilitate the basal uptake of glucose to support the energy needs of the placenta and fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

The correct sequence for the conversion of cholesterol to testosterone involves the enzymes 20, 22 desmolase, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase, 17 alpha hydroxylase, and 17,20 lyase in that specific order.

questions.text: Sodium benzoate is given for urea cycle defects for scavenging ammonia. Which amino acid donates amino group to the scavengers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine

 

Sodium benzoate acts as an ammonia scavenger in urea cycle disorders. It works by conjugating with glycine to form hippurate (or hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine. This process provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion when the urea cycle is impaired. The reaction occurs without requiring the urea cycle, thus helping to reduce ammonia levels in patients with urea cycle disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is actually a component of the urea cycle itself and is often supplemented in some urea cycle disorders (except arginase deficiency). It does not directly conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia removal.

 

Option C. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved with another ammonia scavenger, phenyl butyrate, which is converted to phenyl acetate and then conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. However, glutamine does not conjugate with sodium benzoate.

 

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is an amino acid that participates in the urea cycle by providing one of the nitrogen atoms for urea formation. It does not conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urea cycle disorders, sodium benzoate is used as an ammonia scavenger that conjugates specifically with glycine to form hippurate (hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Reason of Hepatomegaly in Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of glycogen

 

The reason for hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) in this disease is the accumulation of glycogen. Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. When there is a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, the normal breakdown of glycogen into glucose is impaired, leading to the accumulation of glycogen within the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Accumulation of Glucose-6-phosphate: While glucose-6-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis, its accumulation is not the primary cause of hepatomegaly in glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. Increased Glu-6-P however causes other C/f such as Hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia and Lactic acidosis.

 

Option C. Accumulation of Glucose-1-phosphate: Glucose-1-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis. It does not accumulate in Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option D. Accumulation of glycogenin: Glycogenin is a protein that plays a role in initiating glycogen synthesis, not breakdown. Accumulation of glycogenin is not a typical feature of glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.

questions.text: Heavy metal chelators are all EXCEPT:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oxime

 

Oximes are not typically used as heavy metal chelators. Oximes are compounds containing the functional group R1C=NOH. They are more commonly associated with the reactivation of acetylcholinesterase in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillamine: Penicillamine is a heavy metal chelator used in the treatment of Wilson's disease and lead poisoning.

 

Option C. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite or Dimercaprol): BAL is a heavy metal chelator used for arsenic, gold, and mercury poisoning.

 

Option D. Trientine: Trientine is a heavy metal chelator used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heavy metal chelators play a crucial role in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. They work by binding to toxic heavy metals and aiding in their elimination from the body. Each heavy metal chelator may have specific indications and is used for particular heavy metal poisonings.

questions.text: SARS CoV-2 diagnosis is done by all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southern blotting

 

  • Southern blotting is not a standard method for SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis. It is a technique primarily used for the detection and analysis of DNA fragments, not RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2. 
  • Diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) primarily involves detecting viral RNA or immune response markers. Let's break down the options:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR) —Used

  • Gold standard for detecting viral RNA.
  • RNA is reverse-transcribed to DNA, then amplified.
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
     

 

Option B. Real-Time PCR —Used

  • Often used in combination with RT (i.e., RT-qPCR).
  • Provides quantitative data and real-time amplification curves.

 

Option C. Southern Blotting —Not used

  • Southern blotting is used to detect DNA, not RNA.
  • It is not suitable for viral RNA detection.

 

Option D. Immunoassays — Used

  • Used for antibody detection (IgM, IgG) or antigen detection.
  • Examples: ELISA, lateral flow assays (like rapid tests).
  • Useful for screening, epidemiological surveillance, and past infection confirmation.
     

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency room with severe pain in the abdomen. Serum triglyceride level was 1500 mg/dL. Identify the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apo CII

 

The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and extremely elevated triglyceride levels (1500 mg/dL) suggests acute pancreatitis secondary to hypertriglyceridemia, commonly seen in Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia. This condition is characterized by a defect in the lipoprotein lipase (LPL) enzyme or its activator, Apo CII. Apo CII is essential for the activation of LPL, which breaks down triglycerides in the blood. A deficiency or defect in Apo CII prevents this activation, leading to the accumulation of triglycerides and increased risk of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo B 48: This apolipoprotein is essential for the formation of chylomicrons but does not play a role in lipase activation or triglyceride breakdown. Defects in Apo B 48 do not cause elevated triglyceride levels seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Apo B 100: Apo B 100 is critical for the formation of LDL and VLDL particles but does not contribute directly to triglyceride metabolism or cause the acute elevation of triglycerides leading to pancreatitis.

 

Option D. LDL receptor: Defects in LDL receptors are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, leading to elevated LDL cholesterol levels, not triglycerides. It does not contribute to the type of severe hypertriglyceridemia seen in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia, presenting with high triglycerides and abdominal pain, is often due to a defect in lipoprotein lipase or its activator, Apo CII.
